ygData.subject: Re: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results

Subject: Re: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=403065338; y=2vOve0NMeG85ogQ6-rH33r34aWSFlw3R90KQPH10X2dQPKM17eyp3vWAOGs
X-Yahoo-Profile: stephane.doncieux

Hi,

Thanks Ken for going on arguing on this very interesting and important
question.

I don't agree with you relative to quantification. For me, all your
arguments are against a quantification that people think to be
significant at a particular time. It puts one particular quantification
in question, but it is not against quantification in general. Looking
for performance is a criteria that makes sense when your problem is well
posed. It does not mean that it is the only way to proceed, nor that it
is the most interesting one. It has the advantage of the simplicity, but
nothing prevents you from proposing new quantifications.

All the problems you mention are related to the conclusions that are
drawn from the results. If CPPN and a goal-oriented objective can't
generate the pictures you are looking for, all you can deduce is that
the couple CPPN-goal oriented objective does not lead to any interesting
solution... As you said, it is tempting to infer that CPPN can't lead to
the solution, and a lot of papers are built around such conclusions, but
as you said and as other results of yours have shown, it is false. The
fact that quantifications are, sometimes, misleading is nothing else
than a symptom that our interpretation of these quantifications are
wrong. For me, it does not mean that we should stop it, or even stop to
require it. It just means that we need to think about it and update our
way of analysing our results.

The point of JB, is that we need such quantifications to get confidence
in the proposed ideas. Many different ideas can be proposed. Some may be
good and a lot won't be interesting at all. Requiring quantifications
implies to push these ideas far enough so that their potential more
clearly appears. It is possible to demonstrate the potential of an idea
with one single (thought ?) experiment and a careful argumentation, but
it is so difficult that it will remain an exception. Finding a right way
to quantify the results is also thought provoking and interesting per
se. Such a new quantification is a strong contribution to the field,
maybe as important as the initial idea itself.

Best,

stef
